awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Collaborative: Cellular Network Services in Peril: A Perspective on Control-Plane and Data-Plane Design
awd_abstract_narration:
The cellular network is the largest wireless infrastructure deployed today. It offers users mobile Internet access and carrier-grade voice service. Each such service (e.g., data or voice) typically involves operations on both data and control planes. The former transfers service content to users, whereas the latter performs control functions of service instantiation, maintenance, update, and termination. Securing control and data planes is thus critical to mobile network service. Different from the Internet built upon the single best-effort delivery, the fourth-generation (4G) mobile network supports diversified service models. It not only provides multiple priorities within the network (e.g., voice has higher priority than data), but also carries control and data over different radio channels. Consequently, given a service (e.g., voice, video, or messaging), its control-plane and data-plane operations open new venues for security research. This project aims to study both planes in 4G networks from the security perspective. The success of this research will not only protect the trillion-dollar market of mobile voice for billions of smartphone users, but also safeguard the mobile Internet access from attacks initiated by malicious calls. The proposed activity may influence the upcoming 5G technology standardization and train a new generation of engineers and students.

The proposed research has two main thrusts. One is the insecurity analysis of 4G network services. This project examines the control and data planes and their coordination. It conducts thorough theoretical analysis to uncover all potential vulnerabilities, explores novel attacks, and empirically validates those practical threats. The other is to propose defenses to secure both planes from such threats. The solution calls for concerted efforts between the network and the user, and between hardware and software. This project seeks to make three contributions: (1) Systematic disclosure of insecurity on the control-plane and data-plane operations: Both incur new breaches that current defense measures fail to protect; (2) Identification of diverse root causes: Mobile standards stipulate loose regulations, whereas device software and hardware assume protection from each other. As both planes become more accessible to smartphones, no new protection mechanisms are in place. (3) Solution that secures both control-plane and data-plane operations: It adds protection at both hardware and software at mobile devices, and inside the network infrastructure. It further leverages device capabilities while preserving flexible network services.

por.por_cntn:
This project has investigated emerging security issues in 4G voice and messaging services, which are used by billions of mobile users on a daily basis. Each service (here, voice or messaging) involves operations on both data- and control- planes. The former transfers service content to users, whereas the latter performs control functions of service instantiation, maintenance, update, and termination. The service evolution from 3G to 4G and beyond adopts new control-plane and data-plane operations and interplays, thereby opening new venues for security research. Throughout this project, we have successfully disclosed new vulnerabilities in commercial 4G networks, pinpointed their root causes, validated proof-of-concept attacks in the controlled experiments, devised and evaluated defense solutions, and helped to safeguard our current and future cellular networks.

We summarize our main outcomes in two aspects.

Intellectual Merit: Our results have advanced our understanding on emerging security issues in voice and message services in 4G and beyond networks. New vulnerabilities emerge with imprudent design and practice on the interplay between the data-plane and the control-plane; They are exposed to attackers when 4G becomes more open over IP. In particular, we have conducted security analysis primarily in four voice and messaging uses: voice over LTE (VoLTE), circuit-switching fallback (CSFB), WiFi Calling, 4G SMS over IP. We have conducted thorough theoretical analysis to uncover potential vulnerabilities that stem from improper standard designs, device implementation issues and operation slips. We have devised multiple novel attacks like free data access via abusing VoLTE to carry data, overcharging with unauthenticated traffic, overcharging with ID spoofing (for both voice and messaging), voice DDoS, side-channel leakage in WiFi calling, data undercharging etc. We have empirically validated those practical threats in US carriers in our controlled experiments. For the first two voice solutions (VoLTE and CSFB), we have devised practical defense solutions to combat caller ID spoofing.  Our work has resulted in 9 papers in security conferences and journals including CCS'15, CNS'15, CCS'16, HotMobile'16, CNS'18, MobiCom'18, INFOCOM'19, and TMC'20 (2).

Broader Impacts: The vulnerabilities identified by us have been reported to US carriers and involved companies like Google, Facebook and Qualcomm. Some immediate actions have been already taken to not only protect voice and message services for billions of smartphone users, but also safeguard trillion-dollar mobile network infrastructure from malicious exploits and attacks. Our on-device solution against caller ID spoofing has opened up new solution space for the device by the device, which exploits ML to rapidly detect malicious or suspicious behaviors. This gives more power to mobile users as they do not have to wait for the patch or response from the operators, which unfortunately takes a long time, say months or even years. Last but not the least, through curriculum development, graduate/undergraduate advising, and independent studies, this project helps training a new generation of students and workforce in cybersecurity.
